trans-unit.source: Working with Registry Keys
trans-unit.target: Working with Registry Keys

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: Working with Registry Keys
trans-unit.target: Working with Registry Keys

trans-unit.source: Because registry keys are items on Windows PowerShell drives, working with them is very similar to working with files and folders.
trans-unit.target: Because registry keys are items on Windows PowerShell drives, working with them is very similar to working with files and folders.

trans-unit.source: One critical difference is that every item on a registry-based Windows PowerShell drive is a container, just like a folder on a file system drive.
trans-unit.target: One critical difference is that every item on a registry-based Windows PowerShell drive is a container, just like a folder on a file system drive.

trans-unit.source: However, registry entries and their associated values are properties of the items, not distinct items.
trans-unit.target: However, registry entries and their associated values are properties of the items, not distinct items.

trans-unit.source: Listing All Subkeys of a Registry Key
trans-unit.target: Listing All Subkeys of a Registry Key

trans-unit.source: You can show all items directly within a registry key by using **Get-ChildItem**.
trans-unit.target: You can show all items directly within a registry key by using **Get-ChildItem**.

trans-unit.source: Add the optional **Force** parameter to display hidden or system items.
trans-unit.target: Add the optional **Force** parameter to display hidden or system items.

trans-unit.source: For example, this command displays the items directly within Windows PowerShell drive HKCU:, which corresponds to the HKEY_CURRENT_USER registry hive:
trans-unit.target: For example, this command displays the items directly within Windows PowerShell drive HKCU:, which corresponds to the HKEY_CURRENT_USER registry hive:

trans-unit.source: These are the top-level keys visible under HKEY_CURRENT_USER in the Registry Editor (Regedit.exe).
trans-unit.target: These are the top-level keys visible under HKEY_CURRENT_USER in the Registry Editor (Regedit.exe).

trans-unit.source: You can also specify this registry path by specifying the registry provider's name, followed by "**::**".
trans-unit.target: You can also specify this registry path by specifying the registry provider's name, followed by "**::**".

trans-unit.source: The registry provider's full name is **Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\\Registry**, but this can be shortened to just **Registry**.
trans-unit.target: The registry provider's full name is **Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\\Registry**, but this can be shortened to just **Registry**.

trans-unit.source: Any of the following commands will list the contents directly under HKCU:
trans-unit.target: Any of the following commands will list the contents directly under HKCU:

trans-unit.source: These commands list only the directly contained items, much like using Cmd.exe's **DIR** command or **ls** in a UNIX shell.
trans-unit.target: These commands list only the directly contained items, much like using Cmd.exe's **DIR** command or **ls** in a UNIX shell.

trans-unit.source: To show contained items, you need to specify the **Recurse** parameter.
trans-unit.target: To show contained items, you need to specify the **Recurse** parameter.

trans-unit.source: To list all registry keys in HKCU, use the following command (This operation can take an extremely long time.):
trans-unit.target: To list all registry keys in HKCU, use the following command (This operation can take an extremely long time.):

trans-unit.source: **Get-ChildItem** can perform complex filtering capabilities through its **Path**, **Filter**, **Include**, and **Exclude** parameters, but those parameters are typically based only on name.
trans-unit.target: **Get-ChildItem** can perform complex filtering capabilities through its **Path**, **Filter**, **Include**, and **Exclude** parameters, but those parameters are typically based only on name.

trans-unit.source: You can perform complex filtering based on other properties of items by using the **Where-Object**cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can perform complex filtering based on other properties of items by using the **Where-Object**cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The following command finds all keys within HKCU:\\Software that have no more than one subkey and also have exactly four values:
trans-unit.target: The following command finds all keys within HKCU:\\Software that have no more than one subkey and also have exactly four values:

trans-unit.source: Copying Keys
trans-unit.target: Copying Keys

trans-unit.source: Copying is done with **Copy-Item**.
trans-unit.target: Copying is done with **Copy-Item**.

trans-unit.source: The following command copies HKLM:\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion and all of its properties to HKCU:\\, creating a new key named "CurrentVersion":
trans-unit.target: The following command copies HKLM:\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion and all of its properties to HKCU:\\, creating a new key named "CurrentVersion":

trans-unit.source: If you examine this new key in the registry editor or by using **Get-ChildItem**, you will notice that you do not have copies of the contained subkeys in the new location.
trans-unit.target: If you examine this new key in the registry editor or by using **Get-ChildItem**, you will notice that you do not have copies of the contained subkeys in the new location.

trans-unit.source: In order to copy all of the contents of a container, you need to specify the **Recurse** parameter.
trans-unit.target: In order to copy all of the contents of a container, you need to specify the **Recurse** parameter.

trans-unit.source: To make the preceding copy command recursive, you would use this command:
trans-unit.target: To make the preceding copy command recursive, you would use this command:

trans-unit.source: You can still use other tools you already have available to perform filesystem copies.
trans-unit.target: You can still use other tools you already have available to perform filesystem copies.

trans-unit.source: Any registry editing tools—including reg.exe, regini.exe, and regedit.exe—and COM objects that support registry editing (such as WScript.Shell and WMI's StdRegProv class) can be used from within Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Any registry editing tools—including reg.exe, regini.exe, and regedit.exe—and COM objects that support registry editing (such as WScript.Shell and WMI's StdRegProv class) can be used from within Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Creating Keys
trans-unit.target: Creating Keys

trans-unit.source: Creating new keys in the registry is simpler than creating a new item in a file system.
trans-unit.target: Creating new keys in the registry is simpler than creating a new item in a file system.

trans-unit.source: Because all registry keys are containers, you do not need to specify the item type; you simply supply an explicit path, such as:
trans-unit.target: Because all registry keys are containers, you do not need to specify the item type; you simply supply an explicit path, such as:

trans-unit.source: You can also use a provider-based path to specify a key:
trans-unit.target: You can also use a provider-based path to specify a key:

trans-unit.source: Deleting Keys
trans-unit.target: Deleting Keys

trans-unit.source: Deleting items is essentially the same for all providers.
trans-unit.target: Deleting items is essentially the same for all providers.

trans-unit.source: The following commands will silently remove items:
trans-unit.target: The following commands will silently remove items:

trans-unit.source: Removing All Keys Under a Specific Key
trans-unit.target: Removing All Keys Under a Specific Key

trans-unit.source: You can remove contained items by using **Remove-Item**, but you will be prompted to confirm the removal if the item contains anything else.
trans-unit.target: You can remove contained items by using **Remove-Item**, but you will be prompted to confirm the removal if the item contains anything else.

trans-unit.source: For example, if we attempt to delete the HKCU:\\CurrentVersion subkey we created, we see this:
trans-unit.target: For example, if we attempt to delete the HKCU:\\CurrentVersion subkey we created, we see this:

trans-unit.source: To delete contained items without prompting, specify the **-Recurse** parameter:
trans-unit.target: To delete contained items without prompting, specify the **-Recurse** parameter:

trans-unit.source: If you wanted to remove all items within HKCU:\\CurrentVersion but not HKCU:\\CurrentVersion itself, you could instead use:
trans-unit.target: If you wanted to remove all items within HKCU:\\CurrentVersion but not HKCU:\\CurrentVersion itself, you could instead use:
